title: Walter Whiter
text:
The Reverend Walter Whiter (30 October 1758 in <a href="Birmingham%2C%20England">Birmingham, England</a>– 23 July 1832 in <a href="Hardingham">Hardingham</a>) was an English <a href="philologist">philologist</a> and <a href="literary%20critic">literary critic</a>. He is known for his 1794 work "A Specimen of a Commentary on <a href="William%20Shakespeare">Shakspeare</a>". "Specimen", which explored "<a href="As%20You%20Like%20It">As You Like It</a>" in terms of <a href="John%20Locke">John Locke</a>'s philosophy of <a href="associationism">associationism</a>, has been described as the first work of literary criticism to use scientific <a href="psychology">psychology</a>.
In addition to his literary criticism, Whiter published his <a href="etymology">etymological</a> research, first as "Etymologicon Magnum" in 1800, then as "Etymologicon Universale" in 1822 (vol. 1 and 2) and 1825 (vol. 3); August Baron Merian, a correspondent of <a href="Samuel%20Butler%20%28schoolmaster%29">Samuel Butler</a>, stated that he "pit(ied)" Whiter, and described him as "(a) great etymologist—perhaps the greatest that ever lived. A genius certainly; but it seems, like most eminent
artists, <a href="wikt%3Adissolute">dissolute</a>."
Whiter's linguistic studies—in particular, his research into the language used by <a href="Romani%20people">Gypsies</a>—led him to be cited as a role model by <a href="George%20Borrow">George Borrow</a>, to the extent that Whiter appears in Borrow's "<a href="Lavengro">Lavengro</a>" as "Reverend Whiter the philologist". The book includes a song about his character, which goes as follows:
For several decades, Whiter's notes on the vocabulary of <a href="Romani%20language">Romani</a> were thought to have been lost, but were rediscovered and published in 1909 as "Whiter's 'Lingua Cingariana'".
Personal life.
Whiter was a friend of <a href="Richard%20Porson">Richard Porson</a>, who had a habit of adding <a href="marginalia">marginalia</a> to books which Whiter owned; many of these annotations were subsequently collected and published independently.
